          R  Y  Y                   
          G  Y  Y                   
          O  Y  Y                   
 B  R  G  W  R  R  G  G  G  O  O  Y 
 B  R  G  W  G  G  O  O  O  B  B  Y 
 B  R  G  W  O  O  B  B  B  R  R  Y 
          R  W  W                   
          B  W  W                   
          O  W  W                   
 

Please provide a solution to solve this cube.
results.model_answer:
A valid solution using a common layer‐by‐layer method is as follows. (Note that standard cube moves use the notation U (up), D (down), L (left), R (right), F (front), and B (back) along with ’ for counter‐clockwise turns.) 

Step 1. White Cross:
 – Execute: F U R U' R' F'

Step 2. White Corners:
 – Position the white corner pieces using:
  • With the corner below its target position, perform: U R U' R'

Step 3. Middle Layer Edges:
 – Insert an edge from the top layer into its middle slot by doing:
  • If the edge goes to the right: U R U' R' U' F' U F
  • (Mirror the moves if it belongs on the left.)

Step 4. Yellow Cross (Top Face):
 – Form the yellow cross using:
  • F R U R' U' F'

Step 5. Yellow Edge Orientation:
 – Correct the order of the yellow edges with:
  • R U R' U R U2 R'

Step 6. Yellow Corner Adjustment:
 – Finally, position and orient the yellow corners with:
  • For a misoriented corner, apply: U2 L U R' U2 L' R
  • Repeat the corner algorithm as needed until all yellow pieces are correctly placed.

Following these steps (and using the mirror‐algorithms on the opposite sides when required) will solve the cube. Note that depending on the initial configuration you might need to repeat some algorithms more than once; the above sequence should serve as a comprehensive guide to solving the cube.

results.question:
You see a size 3 Rubik's cube. It is arranged this:

          B  R  B                   
          Y  Y  Y                   
          Y  Y  Y                   
 W  B  B  R  R  R  G  G  Y  O  B  O 
 W  R  R  G  G  G  O  O  Y  O  B  O 
 W  B  B  R  R  R  G  G  Y  O  B  O 
          W  W  W                   
          W  W  W                   
          G  O  G                   
 

Please provide a solution to solve this cube.
results.model_answer:
One effective solution is to use the beginner’s “layer‐by‐layer” method. For example, you can follow these steps:

1. White Cross – Form a white cross on the top face. For this configuration, one sample sequence to correctly position an edge piece is:
  F' U L' U'
  (Rotate the front face counterclockwise, then adjust the top and left faces as needed.)

2. White Corners – Insert the white corner pieces to complete the first (white) layer. A typical algorithm for inserting a corner is:
  R U R' U'
  Repeat as necessary until all white corners are in place.

3. Middle Layer – Solve the middle-layer edge pieces. Depending on whether an edge must go to the left or right, you can use one of these algorithms:
  • For a left insertion: U' L' U L U F U' F'
  • For a right insertion: U R U' R' U' F' U F
  Apply the correct one based on the cube’s current state.

4. Yellow Cross – On the opposite (yellow) face, first orient the yellow edges (ignoring corners) with:
  F R U R' U' F'
  This will form a yellow cross.

5. Yellow Edge Orientation – If necessary, adjust the yellow edge pieces with sequences such as:
  R U R' U R U2 R'
  until all yellow edges face upward.

6. Yellow Corner Positioning and Orientation – Finally, position and orient the yellow corners. A common algorithm is to position the corners correctly using:
  U R U' L' U R' U' L
  If a corner is out of place, reposition the top layer (using U moves) and repeat the algorithm until the entire top face is solved.

Note: There is no single “correct” solution sequence – the moves you perform at each stage may vary based on the cube’s configuration. Many solvers now use computer‐assisted algorithms (like Kociemba’s) for an optimized move count. The above steps give an example method that, if followed carefully and adjusted as needed, will lead to a solved cube.

Happy cubing!

This method (a variation of the CFOP/beginner’s method) will solve the cube from the given starting position.

You see a size 3 Rubik's cube. It is arranged this:

          O  O  Y                   
          G  Y  B                   
          G  Y  B

 G  R  R  W  G  Y  O  O  O  W  Y  Y 
          B  W  G                   
          B  W  G                   
          R  R  G                   
 

Please provide a solution to solve this cube.
results.model_answer:
A valid solution (using the beginner‐method) is as follows:

1. White Cross:
  • Position the white–edge pieces so that white forms a cross on the white face.
   Example moves (adjusting for your cube’s orientation):
    F  U  R  U′  R′  F′

2. White Corners:
  • Insert and correctly orient the white corners to complete the white face.
   Example insertion (for one corner):
    R  U  R′  U′

3. Middle–Layer Edges:
  • Place the middle–layer edge pieces into their correct positions.
   For an edge destined for the left, you might use:
    U′  L′  U  L  U  F  U′  F′
   For an edge destined for the right, mirror the moves.

4. Yellow Cross:
  • With the white face complete (and thus yellow on top), form a yellow cross.
   Use the algorithm:
    F  R  U  R′  U′  F′
   Repeat as needed until a cross appears on the yellow face.

5. Yellow Face Orientation:
  • Once the yellow cross is formed, orient and align the yellow edges.
   A common approach is to use:
    U  R  U′  L′  U  R′  U′  L
   Repeat (and rotate the top face as needed) until all yellow pieces are correctly oriented.

6. Yellow Corners – Permutation:
  • Finally, permute the yellow corners so that every face’s colors match.
   An effective sequence is:
    U  R  U′  L′  U  R′  U′  L
   If one corner remains out of place, use a corner–cycling algorithm (perform the above sequence while holding the mis‐oriented corner in the back/right) until complete.

Following these stages and adapting the moves to the specific positions of your cube’s pieces will solve the cube. Note that exactly which moves to use at each step depends on your cube’s state; the algorithms above are standard “building–block” sequences that, when applied in the proper order, will solve a valid 3×3 Rubik’s Cube.

results.model_answer:
Here’s one complete beginner‐method solution (using standard face notation) for the cube:

1. Solve the white cross on the bottom (white face):
 • Position the white edge pieces to form a cross with matching side colors.
  – For example, if a white edge is in the top layer, use moves like “F U R U′” (adjust as needed) until its white sticker is on D and its side color aligns with its center.

2. Insert the white corner pieces:
 • Locate a white corner in the top layer and bring it beneath its intended position.
 • Use the algorithm “R′ D′ R D” (repeat as needed) to insert each corner correctly.

3. Complete the middle layer (the second layer):
 • For an edge piece on the top that belongs in the middle layer, align its non‐yellow color with the center.
 • If it needs to go to the right, perform: “U R U′ R′ U′ F′ U F.”
 • If it goes to the left, perform the mirror: “U′ L′ U L U F U′ F′.”

4. Form the yellow cross on the top face:
 • With yellow on top, use: “F R U R′ U′ F′.”
 • You might need to repeat this procedure until a full cross (ignoring the corner pieces) is obtained.

5. Orient the yellow face:
 • With a cross in place, adjust so all yellow stickers face upward.
 • Use the algorithm “R U R′ U R U2 R′” to orient the yellow corners (execute it whenever a corner is misoriented).

6. Permute (swap) the yellow corners:
 • With the top fully yellow, you may need to reposition the yellow corners.
 • Execute “U R U′ L′ U R′ U′ L” to cycle the corners until all are in the correct location.

7. Permute the yellow edges (if needed):
 • Finally, if the top edge pieces are not in the right order, use a final edge permutation algorithm such as “R2 U′ R′ U′ R U R2.”

Following these steps and adjusting move sequences based on the cube’s look at each stage will lead you to a solved Rubik’s Cube.

 • For an edge that must go to the left, use: U′, L′, U, L, U, F, U′, F′.
 • For an edge that belongs on the right, use: U, R, U′, R′, U′, F′, U, F.

 • Find an edge piece in the top layer that belongs in the middle.

  If it belongs on the left, mirror the moves.

  Repeat until a “yellow cross” appears.

  Apply it until the top face is entirely yellow.

  Turn only the face with the misoriented corner; when it is correctly oriented, rotate just the top layer (U) to bring the next misoriented corner into place and repeat.
